description.text: A tank tread that I designed for an arduino powered tank.
I created this tank tread for tracked R/C vehicles.  It easily connects together with other copies of iteself by using nail brads.

comments.text: What size are "nail brads" that this is designed for? I looked them up, and as far as I can tell, "nail brads" come in a range of sizes and gauges. I printed the part, and it's TINY - it looks like they'd be held together with staples, and I couldn't quite slide a resister lead through the holes.

This gear, in conjunction with my chain Thing will work in a number of applications, from robotics to toys.
Print two of these gears and a couple dozen links, connect them with nail brads, and you've got a chain & sprocket system.

I'm still learning the ins and outs of modeling. So building a pcb cover for my Mendel 90 seemed like a good project to practice on.  
Sliced at 0.2 layer height with a perimeter of 2 using PLA.  
**UPDATE - Added a second version with a few vent holes and the "MENDEL90" text knocked out for additional air flow.

comments.text:
Le tube est pour une bobine avec un trou de quel diamètre ? Les miennes sont d'un diamètre de 52mm, PLA eSun ou MotionTech.
Ajout : Dans Cura les infos de taille me donne 36mm de diamètre, longueur 98cm. J'ai des bobines de 1kg, elles sont plus larges semble t il. Et du coup en changeant les valeurs X et Y de Cura je peux l'avoir à la bonne dimension. par contre cela augmente le diamètre de l'axe pour le support et cela n'es pas modifiable avec le STL seulement.

Not just for beehive hairdos and potato cannons anymore - AQUANET Extra Super Hold hair spray may just be what you have been looking for to improve your 3D printer's first layer adhesion. I made huge improvements with my leveling procedure ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23257 ). Still, over time, even when my Kapton tape looked good and the build plate was level, parts would not stick. Putting on fresh Kapton tape was the only thing that fixed this particular problem but it is a pain to do, the tape is expensive and I am cheap and lazy. As luck would have it, I just happened to have a can of this hairspray laying around from a potato cannon project and thought "What the heck?". It does say "Super strong hold" on the can so I gave it a try. Like that first meeting of chocolate and peanut butter I had my "Eureka" moment. I have not tried with large prints yet, but I did do an entire week of building miscellaneous small to medium sized parts with only one build plate level and perfectly bonded parts. There was no edge lifting even on parts that had a first layer chamfer! It has to be good it has the word Miracle in the title!

WARNING! Make sure the build plate is cool! Keep away from sparks and flames and all that! This stuff is flammable - think James Bond!

  • Make sure your build plate is level first.
    -- That is the biggest issue with the Replicator IMHO.
    -- http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23257

  • Go to the Dollar Tree and pick up a can (unless your wife's name is Flo and she works in a diner - then just use hers!) Also available on Amazon - http://www.amazon.com/Aqua-Net-Professional-Spray-Extra/dp/B001VFT0VS/ref=reg_hu-rd_add_1_dp

  • Use some kind of a mask to keep from gumming up your rails and bearings and such.
    -- I have included files to make a cardboard mask.

  • Spray a light mist over build plate
    -- A little goes a long way
    -- A week later and I am still using my first spray's worth
    • NOTE: The hairspray has lots of multisyllabic chemical names on the ingredient list. I make no claims as to its safety. UPDATE: I tried White Rain Extra Hold and it doesn't work well. The ingredients are almost the same but it doesn't have the VA/Crotonates/Vinyl or the Neodecanoate Copolymer. Must be what makes the Aquanet work?!

comments.text: NO! The meeting of chocolate and peanut butter was a "eurrgh" moment, not a "Eureka" moment.
comments.author: NilByMouth

comments.text: Wiped my glass with a paper towel soaked with acetone/ABS slurry, then coated it with Extra Super Hold Unscented Aqua Net. 5 parts have printed in the last few hours perfectly flat that warped and/or broke loose every time I tried them before!

comments.text: My success with this was limited. I think there was some effect, but changing the tape gives a much better improvement, I'd say.

comments.text: Just spread pva glue then dry with hair dryer
comments.author: egil

comments.text: Hi guys.....Im doing some large prints, with a large area on first layer. Warping has been driving me crazy and I just bought some hairspray to test if this helps. My main concern is that hairspray is flamable and Im basicly applying melted plastic and a heated metal extruder to it.....so I was wondering if anyone has some pointers on how to avoid fire hazzards, what temperature is a no no and if this problem will only present during the first layers, as sometimes prints take over 8 hours and I tend to just leave the printer working overnight. Any advise is more than welcome, I dont want to start a fire just for being careless..........
comments.author: wachong

comments.text:
I use Aqua net extra super hold and sometimes can use one spray application for several duplcate parts in the same spot without the addition of extra spray. Also moving your prints around on the platform will make it last much longer between sprays. Just tap your finger on the area your going to print and see if the hairspray feels slightly tacky if so, go for it. For large area prints, let the bed cool and it will just usually pop off on its own. Prying off large parts will warp them and they stick so well, you stand a chance of cracking your glass, small ones are usually ok to pry off and start the next print job. I usually spray the entire build plate glass, then touch up with light sprays (if needed) in used spots on the glass.
I also use fine and medium sandings sponge to buff off and even out the old dryed hairspray residue and can continue to print by adding another layer of hairspray. I can print all day every day for four or five days before neededing clean the broc-glass off by spraying it down with regular old glass cleaner that has ammonia in it and letting it soak for 5 or 10 minutes then use a green kitchen scrub on it. Its super easy to clean off the hairspray! No effort at all!
I like hairspray 1000% better than using tape or sheets.. Lots less hassle. Just got to be sure not to spray your machine parts, screws rails etc. Using 110 bed temp on ABS, 3mm @ 220 extruder temp. Ultimate MendelMax.
comments.author: Jwill76524

comments.text: Tried this and it seems to work.  The break away force required is less than PVA glue and WAY less than slurry.  I was able to snap the part off without having to use tools, which usually tear holes in the Kapton tape.
comments.author: LeftAngle

comments.text: Are you printing with ABS or PLA? I've never had trouble with ABS sticking to kapton, so long as I wipe it down with alcohol and heat to 100C. However, I've had exactly the experience you describe with PLA. It works pretty well on Kapton at 55C, but eventually even cleaning it with acetone doesn't work anymore and the Kapton has to be replaced to get anything to stick well. Of course it sticks like crazy to blue tape, but then you destroy the tape on every print, which is a real pain. I'm curious if this hairspray thing will work with PLA. I guess there's one way to find out...
comments.author: emmett

comments.text: It works great I'm using painters tape and hair spray and my PLA never comes up
comments.author: emmett

comments.text: Looking forward to hearing the results of your experimentation!
comments.author: emmett

comments.text: Hmm..heep it in mind - although I have never had a problem with adhesion.   I print in ABS - but I do crank my platform up to 120. - No issues w/ warping ot having parts pop off..in fact if I don't let the platform cool to 60-70 it's nearly impossible to pull the parts off.
comments.author: UechiMike

comments.text: Hairspray is magic! Try to print on Depron /  Styrofoam with an Ink-Jet printer and you wil fail... prepare the sstyrofoam with strong hairspray and it wil work!
comments.author: tanis

comments.text: Have you tried just cleaning the platform with acetone (or even rubbing alcohol)? My guess is that the solvent in the hairspray has more to do with the improved platform adhesion than whatever adhesives are in the hairspray, and the adhesives and perfumes and whatnot in the hairspray are likely to build up and make the thing dirty and hurt print adhesion in the long run.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: I just use really watered down PVA glue (RichRap and someone else gave me the idea but can't remember who). It's alot cheaper than haispray and you can use a paint brush to put it on and control where it goes. Plus as it is watered down it will self level that last little bit that you can never get just right. The heated bed will evaporate and dry the PVA very quickly.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: Yes, I have done the cleaning thing - Acetone, Ethenol, Isoporopyl etc..  My guess is something changes on the surface of the Kapton over time.   In the past the only thing that "fixed" this particular problem was replacing the Kapton.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: Have you tried wiping down with acetone while there is still a little plastic (single-layer skirts are great for this) on it? The acetone dissolves the spreads a fine film of it on the platform that will make parts stick like you wouldn't believe. I keep nail polish bottles of acetone with these scraps pre-dissolved in them for this purpose.
comments.author: phineasjw

comments.text: "Slurry" is typically thicker than "juice". I prefer to keep stuff more on the "slurry" side, because this is also useful for gluing ABS parts together, smoothing them, or reinforcing weak mechanical parts.

remixed_from.author: RichRap
remixed_from.title: Dual Printable T-Slot nut for MendelMax

remixed_from.author: kludgineer
remixed_from.title: Printable T-Slot nut for Misumi Extrusions

title: M5 T-slot nut substitute
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Off-the-shelf T-slot nuts are incredibly expensive. So many have set out to replace those with printed parts, always replicating how those nuts work thus putting a lot of pressure on the printed nut.
With this thing, all load of the joint is put on a 1mm washer, held in place together with the M5 half-nut.
This substitute prints without support and should be sliced at 0.2mm layer-height. If sliced at a different height, chances are it won't fit. This part served as a T-Slot nut substitute for my MendelMax build, using http://uk.rs-online.com/web/p/products/837-234/ nuts and http://uk.rs-online.com/web/p/products/525-931/ washers together with KJN extrusions. The OpenSCAD file contains part of Catarina Motas Shape Library: http://svn.makerbot.com/users/hoeken/openscad/shapes.scad

1) print many of them
2) insert nuts and washers
3) be happy that you saved a lot of money

comments.text: If you derived this from two GPL projects, how can you make the derivative NC?
comments.author: jebba

comments.text:
In this case the derivation is more like inspiration rather than actual asset reuse. This thing is developed from scratch and the items I "derived" it from were more like the starting points that made me design it in the first place.
Thus I'm not bound by the GPL in this case and get to choose the licence.

comments.text: Forget what these chaps bellow are saying (except wilot309) this is a very good design. The only force applied to theÂ plastic partÂ is rotational. It acts like a wrench holding the nut in place whenÂ tighteningÂ the screw, after that all it does isÂ keeps the nut and washerÂ centeredÂ in the channel so they cant move and pop out.
comments.author: thecrazy

comments.text: The naysayers below have probably not printed or tried this solution - I have and it is ROCK SOLID. Not only is it fit-for-purpose (as described), it is also the cheapest solution.
comments.author: thecrazy

comments.text: Glad to ear it! Never needed them as i had plenty in stock but ill give them a try before reordering. Thanks for the review!
comments.author: Poida

comments.text: Very nice, I like how this is simplified from the ones it is derived from, I did not see the point in the extra plastic that was in the groove of the T-slot nad now you are able to add a washer.
comments.author: wilot309

comments.text: that is correct, the plastic only holds the nut and washer in place. Once tightened, the plastic part is only needed then the nut is to be loosened again.
comments.author: wilot309

comments.text: Won't be as strong as a real metal t-nut, but may do just fine for many uses. I've always just purchased carriage bolts and then ground off two opposite sides of the flange on the bolt. That makes a t-bolt instead of a t-nut, but most of the time you can use that instead. On the rare cases where a t-nut is really required, I've used a thick washer with the edges ground off in combination with a nut. They can be epoxied together to keep them from falling apart when you insert them. This design is great for light use.
comments.author: JamesNewton

comments.text: I don't get it.  Aren't these pretty much useless?  Your design doesn't actually trap the nut, so once you tighten the nut, it just slips through the printed T-slot piece.  You'd be better off not printing anything and just using the washer.
comments.author: thantik

comments.text: thantik, it goes the other way round. They are upside down in the picture. Imagine the bolt coming up through the table, thru the printed part and /ending/ at the metal nut.

If you look at the pieces you derived this from you'll notice that the nut trap does not go entirely through like yours does. That's for good reason. Your design is flawed and basically serves no purpose in its current form.
comments.author: JamesNewton

comments.text: The nut is trapped by the aluminium extrusion itself and does not slide through. Besides, if printed on a well calibrated machine, the nut is pres-fit into the part. There is good reason not to trap the nut completely, as it allows for some tolerance in regards to nut thickness.

Exactly.  The nut isn't trapped by any 3d printed part.  Looking at the design, the nut is free to basically sail right through the piece.  Screw it in outside of T-slot exactly like you're saying, and then pull on the printed piece.  It'll slip right off.
comments.author: JamesNewton

comments.text: you would be incorrect.. after printing them the nut is press fit with the washer on top and a tight fit in the extrusion. once the screw/bolt is even slightly tight the plastic is no longer an issue and it tightness right up. wouldn't recommend a lot of disassambly/rebuild of them but for a set it and forget it. They work like a charm

This bracket can be used on either end of the gear, but may require some modifications to the gear's main rod where the end stops are located.
This item becomes its own linear bearing when you insert BBs into the inner ring.  There is a trick to putting all the bbs into the ring before putting the gear rod through.

comments.text: To make the item a bearing;  hold the shaft vertical, insert it into bracket, push shaft in until it barely begiens to cover the internal bearing ring, pour BBs into the bracket, push them into the bearing ring, when ring is full, push shaft all the way through.  Excess BBs will pop out as you push the rod through.
comments.author: moltenplastic

This gear works in conjunction with the tank tread in my collection.

The slots in the gear itself are where the brads of the tread fit into.
The gear can be further modified to have spokes that can fit into the holes in the center of each tank tread, offering a second seat of purchase.
